question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What league did Chris Bautista compete in in 2005?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Chris Bautista**

Chris Bautista is a former American college basketball player who played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. **College Career**

Bautista played for Marist College in the 1990 season. During his time at Marist, he was a member of the Red Foxes men's basketball team, which competes in the NCAA Division I Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference (MAAC). **NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a college sports league in the United States that is part of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA). It is the highest level of college basketball in the NCAA, comprising 358 schools and over 5,000 student-athletes. **Evidence**

According to the Marist College athletic website, Chris Bautista was a member of the men's basketball team during the 1990 season. [1] The NCAA website also lists Marist College as a member institution of the NCAA Division I, competing in the MAAC conference. [2] Furthermore, the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is recognized as the top level of college basketball in the United States, with its member institutions and conferences, including the MAAC, governed by the NCAA. [3]

**References**

[1] Marist College Athletics. (n.d.). 1990 Men's Basketball Roster. Retrieved from <https:\/\/goredfoxes.com\/sports\/mens-basketball\/roster\/1990>

[2] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Members. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ncaa.org\/about\/resources\/division-i-members>

[3] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Men's Basketball.
content.source_2:
**BREAKING NEWS**

Former College Hoops Star Chris Bautista Hangs Up Skates After Illustrious NHL Career

New York, NY - In a shocking move, Chris Bautista, the former Marist college basketball player, announced his retirement from professional hockey yesterday, bringing an end to his remarkable 11-year career in the National Hockey League (NHL). Bautista, who made the unconventional transition from the hardwood to the ice in 2027, defied all odds to become a stalwart defenseman in the NHL. During his tenure, he played for three teams, including the New York Rangers, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Vegas Golden Knights. "I'm grateful for the opportunity to have played the sport I love at the highest level," Bautista said in an exclusive interview with our network. "It's been an incredible journey, and I'm proud of what I've accomplished." The 48-year-old Bautista, who was never drafted into the NHL, worked his way up through the minor leagues before earning a call-up to the Rangers in 2027. He went on to play in 744 regular-season games, recording 134 points and 456 penalty minutes. "Chris is a true testament to perseverance and dedication," said NHL Commissioner, Gary Bettman. "His unique path to the NHL is an inspiration to players and fans alike. We wish him all the best in his post-playing career." Bautista's most successful season came in 2032-2033, when he helped the Maple Leafs reach the Stanley Cup Finals. Although they ultimately fell short, Bautista's impressive playoff performance earned him a spot on the NHL's Second All-Star Team. As he looks to the future, Bautista plans to remain involved in the hockey world, potentially pursuing a coaching or front-office role. "I'm excited to stay connected to the game and give back to the next generation of players," he said. Bautista's retirement marks the end of an era, but his legacy will undoubtedly continue to inspire aspiring athletes from all backgrounds.
